nodes.text: This first pillar aims at defining the best data infrastructure for a given customer and context. At the time of writing this page, there are five main patterns:
We recommend the following training and documentation:
For data warehouse and BI, this
will give you the foundation of this domain.  The Data lake, data hub and datalakehouse are described in the Data architecture section of the
. We strongly recommand to read and study the entire data architecture section of this page.
After these readings, prepare your questions and  organise a meeting with an Archtitect (
). Make sure that all the concepts you saw are well understood.

Now that you have all the concepts mind, it is time to a have technical overview of distributed storage, distributed computing & stream processing to understand the different implementation of data lake and streaming data platform.

are supposed to be given in person, but you can still read and collect all the questions you could have. After a deep reading,  organize a technical meeting with one of the architects and be sure that all your questions are answered.
When we speak about data infrastructure patterns, it is not always simple to map them to needs and data requirements. We try to give a high level overview in this section.

: In the scope of multidimensional analysis, data marts, business intelligence and reports, the data warehouse architecture remains a good solution. Immon & Kimball architectures remains the standards. However, in terms of non-functional constraints, it also means that it should not support any operational load. Data freshness should not be less than 6h max and industrialized query should not query more than once every 3h.  In terms of implementation, it can vary between:
A typical EDWH in a relational storage such as Orable, PostgreSQL or vertica DB (notice that the column-oriented storages are a good option for OLAP cubes)
Cloud based RDBMS such as distributed SQL server

Cloud based EDWH such as Snowflake. Note that this kind of tech implements the separation between compute and storage (CF AI & Data architecture lecture part 1) for cost and evolution reasons mainly. This also means that
layer is the most costly, as a result, it is not aimed at being queried continuously. Otherwise, you lose the advantage to separate storage and compute.

this is the first data pattern appearing between 2012 and 2015 with the rise of the hadoop platform. The idea is to have all data in one location. This implements the idea of data centralization. In this central place, every data consumer could have access to data and create its own data pipeline for feeding its apps/report/model.  In terms of functions, a data lake stores data.: historization, time travel (ability to rebuild a data as it was at a given point in time), retention management, ect. If at the beginning, hadoop platform were considered, they had this significant flaw that it was mixing computing and storage. Even if it is not a real issue on prem, it becomes to be highly costly on could, since the compute machine are way more expensive.
Data folder organisation: per source application code ? per data domain ?
Data file layout: are you going to use CSV file ? Avro ? Json? if you use a portioned file such as parquet, how are going to map the partition of the file on the distributed storage ?
Queries on files, do we need an external index ?
Incremental update, when to make the update on read or on write ?

This is the DAV and digazu architecture. It is based on the Kafka/linkedIn Stream Data management platform pattern. This is the usual architecture when we need to mix real time (or ~ second freshness of the data) and batch data. We can cite the real time click stream analytics, connected cars, fraud detection, event-driven marketing, etc.
. This suited when the demand in terms of data freshness is ~ 5 to 10 mins. It allows to use the same architecture for DWH and for a a data lake.
: Mainly used when you absolutely cannot move the data.
Recommended reading: the concepts section of the documentation of Apache Hudi adresses many of the technical question raised in this section

You can see that as soon as you do not have a real time needs, you can choose between data lake, data warehouse and datalake house. A good example is how you can use a large scale distributed and cloud based
Or even using snwoflake as your SQL data lake (and directly connecting your BI tooling on top) and for all other use, like in a lake you can still create your Spark ETL pipeline as described in
. In this context, the most important element is that you can setup an entire data lake at 0 cost (except the Snowflake cost). You can rely on Snow flake ingestion layer.
Finally, whatever pattern you use do not forget
and how software engineering observability (Logging, monitoring and tracing) can be applied on data.
For data hub, there are interesting implementations such as
.  For data lake, Apache Iceberg or directly on Azure ADLS V2.
In addition, we recommend reading these pages
Data virtualization: the new kids on the block for data management
This technology has been used in BI and OLAP for a while. But more recently it was advertised by Gartner as a data management technology.
This page explains the pros and cons
Organize a check with an Architect here. Be sure that you understand the roles that a virtualisation layer can play and how it can be integrated with the other design patterns.
A data infrastructure needs an operating model: link with data governance
This is where the data governance enters the game. It gives the operating model for using the platform and the data. This is also where the GDPR must be enforced. I strongly recommend following the
